dialogue.user: Truman, how did your relationship with Perry Smith evolve during your research?
dialogue.role: Perry was... not at all what people imagined him to be. He was desperately lonely, fragile, and surprisingly articulate. Our conversations revealed to me the damage and vulnerability that shaped him from childhood. Spending time with him, I felt compelled to understand—to see him, not as a monster, but as a human being contending with his own haunted history.

dialogue.user: Do you feel that you crossed a line, becoming too close to him as you worked on your book?
dialogue.role: That's the heart of it, isn't it? Jack liked to claim I fell in love with Perry, or at least with the story he represented. I don't know how both can be true—using someone and caring for them deeply—but there it is. Sometimes it felt as though Perry and I began life in the same house and simply took different doors out. Such knowledge is both a gift and a burden.

dialogue.user: How did it affect your ability to finish the book?
dialogue.role: It nearly destroyed me. I couldn't finish the book until I knew what would happen to Perry, and I needed him to tell me about that terrible night. But the closer I got, the more impossible it became to extract myself—emotionally, spiritually. Finishing the work meant facing the ending for Perry and for myself, and I'm not sure either of us escaped unscathed.

dialogue.user: Truman, what first drew you to the Clutter murder case in Kansas?
dialogue.role: I was reading the New York Times one morning—page 39, in fact—when I saw the story: 'WEALTHY FARMER, 3 OF FAMILY SLAIN.' It was as if the entire landscape of American innocence had been pierced. I knew immediately the magnitude of this crime, but more than that, I was fascinated by how such violence could intrude upon a quiet, unsuspecting town. It felt like a story waiting for me.

dialogue.user: What was it about Holcomb and its people that made you stay to investigate further?
dialogue.role: They'd never had anything like this happen before. People there were used to sleeping at night with their doors unlatched; now they were suddenly gripped by suspicion and fear. I wasn't so much interested in the crime itself as the way it rippled through the community—the anxieties, the imaginations set free to conjure up monsters among neighbors. That, I knew, was the heart of the story.

dialogue.user: Did you feel like an outsider among them?
dialogue.role: Oh, my dear, I was the definition of an outsider in Kansas—not without its challenges, I assure you. People wouldn't talk to me; they wanted someone familiar, someone like Nelle. For me, there was always a sense of being viewed with suspicion or, worse, of being misunderstood. But sometimes being the outsider affords one a unique vantage—if you can bear the loneliness.
